summary: This is the prepared testimony of David E. Patton, Executive Director of Federal Defenders of New York, before a House Judiciary subcommittee oversight hearing on the Federal Bureau of Prisons and the implementation of the First Step Act. The testimony criticizes BOP's history of mismanagement, citing the 2019 power outage crisis at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn and the suicide of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan as examples of systemic failures. It raises concerns about the BOP's ability to faithfully implement the First Step Act, particularly regarding programming, the PATTERN risk assessment tool, and the closure of Residential Reentry Centers. A letter from the Federal Public Defender for the Western District of Washington to the Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, Kathleen Hawk Sawyer, detailing systemic Bureau practices that are causing the closure and financial endangerment of reentry centers (halfway houses) across the United States. The letter argues these practices contradict Congressional mandates like the Second Chance Act and the First Step Act, and urges immediate corrective action. This document contains a letter from Federal Public Defender Thomas W. Hillier to the Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, Thomas R. Kane, providing formal comment on proposed regulations implementing the Second Chance Act's pre-release community confinement provisions. The letter argues the BOP's proposed regulation fails to comply with congressional mandates, should incorporate a presumption of maximum community corrections, and should reject an informal six-month limitation rule. An attachment lists Residential Reentry Center contracts expiring or not being renewed in 2017-2018. This document is a compilation of news articles from Reuters and CNN (dated 2017-2019) and a related Bureau of Prisons internal memorandum from October 2017. It details the Trump administration's decision to cut funding and cancel contracts for 16 federal halfway houses (Residential Reentry Centers), citing fiscal constraints. The articles include reactions from judges, advocacy groups, and affected individuals, framing the cuts as contrary to criminal justice reform efforts. This document is the Bureau of Prisons' 2018 annual report to Congress on the utilization of community corrections facilities (Residential Reentry Centers and home confinement), as required by the Second Chance Act. It provides statistical data from April 2017 through March 2018, explains eligibility criteria, and outlines recent activities and future goals for inmate reentry programs.

events.title: Fire and Power Outage at MDC Brooklyn
events.description: A fire at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn knocked out power, leading to a week-long crisis with no heat, light, or power for medical equipment during freezing temperatures.

events.title: Court-Ordered Access to MDC
events.description: Chief Judge Dora Irizarry ordered the Federal Defenders be given access to the MDC, revealing horrific conditions five days after the power outage began.

events.title: Suicide of Jeffrey Epstein at MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan, bringing intense scrutiny to the facility.

events.title: DOJ Releases PATTERN Report
events.description: The Department of Justice issued a report announcing the initial development of the PATTERN risk and needs assessment system under the First Step Act.

events.title: Congressional Oversight Hearing on BOP and First Step Act
events.description: House Judiciary Subcommittee on Crime, Terrorism, and Homeland Security held an oversight hearing where David Patton delivered this testimony.

events.title: Closure of Residential Reentry Centers
events.description: At least 20 reentry centers closed or stopped accepting federal inmates, undermining the goals of the First Step Act and Second Chance Act.

events.title: FPD Letter on Second Chance Act Implementation
events.description: Federal Public Defender Thomas Hillier writes to BOP Director Thomas Kane to express concern about the Bureau's failure to implement the Second Chance Act of 2007.

events.title: GAO Report on BOP Practices
events.description: The Government Accountability Office issues a report noting the Bureau of Prisons' failure to adequately implement Congressionally mandated alternative options to incarceration, including reentry centers.

events.title: BOP Non-Renewal of Reentry Center Contracts
events.description: The Bureau of Prisons chooses not to renew contracts with 16 reentry centers around the country, citing the 'fiscal environment'.

events.title: Enactment of the First Step Act
events.description: The First Step Act is enacted by a bipartisan congressional majority, potentially requiring greater use of reentry centers through earned credit programs.

events.title: Closure of Mahoney Hale in Honolulu
events.description: The Mahoney Hale reentry center in Honolulu, Hawaii, closes after the BOP's contract renewal process sought an unfeasibly low number of beds, leaving the state without a federal reentry center.

events.title: Letter to BOP Director Sawyer
events.description: The Federal Public Defender for the Western District of Washington sends this detailed letter to BOP Director Kathleen Hawk Sawyer outlining the crisis in reentry center capacity and urging immediate action.

events.title: BOP Proposes Regulation on Pre-Release Confinement
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons publishes a proposed regulation in the Federal Register (76 Fed. Reg. 58197) implementing the pre-release community confinement provision of the Second Chance Act.

events.title: Federal Public Defender Submits Comment
events.description: Thomas W. Hillier, Federal Public Defender for the Western District of Washington, submits a formal comment letter to the BOP criticizing the proposed regulation for failing to implement the Second Chance Act's intent.

events.title: Judge Invalidates BOP Regulation
events.description: Judge Marsh of the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon invalidates an earlier BOP regulation related to community corrections in the case Sacora v. Thomas.

events.title: Trump Administration Cuts Halfway House Support
events.description: As reported by Reuters, the Trump administration reduces support for prisoner halfway houses, severing contracts with up to 16 facilities, potentially forcing inmates to stay in prison longer.

events.title: BOP Memo on RRC Contract Cuts
events.description: The Bureau of Prisons' Reentry Services Division issued an internal memorandum announcing the discontinuation of 16 underutilized Residential Reentry Center contracts, affecting 146 beds, to remain within budget.

events.title: CNN Reports on Halfway House Cuts

keyFacts: The testimony details a severe week-long crisis in January 2019 at the MDC Brooklyn where a fire caused a power outage, leaving inmates in freezing, dark cells without adequate medical care or communication.

Jeffrey Epstein's suicide at the MCC Manhattan is cited as an example of the systemic problems within federal pretrial facilities, though the author states he has no personal knowledge of the circumstances.

The Federal Defenders raise significant concerns about the BOP's implementation of the First Step Act, particularly the transparency, fairness, and potential racial bias of the new PATTERN risk assessment tool.

The testimony alleges a pattern of BOP mismanagement and lack of accountability, exemplified by the promotion of MDC Warden Herman Quay after he was found to have lied about conditions during the crisis.
A major implementation failure noted is the closure of at least 20 Residential Reentry Centers since 2017, which cripples the rehabilitative goals of the First Step Act and Second Chance Act.

The Bureau of Prisons is systematically reducing reentry center capacity through non-renewal of contracts, soliciting contracts for fewer beds with reduced payment guarantees, and decreasing the length of pre-release stays for inmates.
These practices have led to the closure of reentry centers in multiple states including Hawaii, Maine, North Carolina, and Michigan, often without consulting the affected federal judicial districts.
The BOP's actions contradict Congressional mandates in the Second Chance Act (2007) and the First Step Act (2018), which were designed to expand the use of reentry centers to reduce recidivism.
A 2017 memorandum from BOP Acting Assistant Director Hugh Hurwitz explicitly linked reduced reentry center stays to 'fiscal constraints'.

The letter urges Director Sawyer to issue emergency directives to halt further closures, formalize supportive policies, and ensure individualized assessments for up to a year of pre-release time as authorized by law.

The Federal Public Defender argues the BOP's proposed regulation for the Second Chance Act violates Congress's mandate by failing to establish rules for the 'optimal duration' of pre-release community corrections.
The letter claims the BOP maintains an informal 'six-month rule' for community confinement that lacks empirical support and nullifies the Act's intent to allow up to twelve months.
Financial analysis in the letter estimates the BOP could save hundreds of millions of dollars annually by maximizing the use of home confinement and halfway houses instead of prison.
An attachment lists 16 Residential Reentry Center (RRC) contracts across the U.S. that were expiring or not being renewed in 2017-2018.
An attached Reuters article reports the Trump administration was 'quietly cutting support' for halfway houses in 2017, severing contracts and potentially extending prison stays.
The Federal Bureau of Prisons, under the Trump administration, discontinued 16 contracts with halfway houses (Residential Reentry Centers) in October 2017, affecting 146 beds.
The BOP cited fiscal constraints and underutilization as reasons, but critics argued the cuts harmed prisoner re-entry and were at odds with criminal justice reform trends.
A bipartisan group of eight U.S. senators, including John Cornyn and Chuck Grassley, sent a letter protesting the cuts, warning they could make communities less safe.
The internal BOP memorandum from October 10, 2017, explicitly states the cuts were to keep the RRC program 'within budgetary allocations'.
The document includes a 2019 solicitation for new RRC and home confinement services in Oklahoma, indicating the contracting process continued after the 2017 cuts.
From April 2017 to March 2018, 34,738 federal inmates were eligible for transfer to Residential Reentry Centers (RRCs) or home confinement; 72% (25,000) were transferred.
The average expected length of stay in an RRC for inmates releasing during that period was 136.8 days, a decrease from the previous fiscal year.

Common reasons for inmate ineligibility for community transfer included release to a detainer (22,304 cases, mostly by ICE), sentences of six months or less, and failure to satisfy financial obligations.
The Bureau of Prisons has implemented a web-based electronic RRC application system nationally, processing over 200,000 referrals to increase efficiency.
The report is a statutory requirement under the Second Chance Act of 2007, mandating the BOP Director to report annually to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees.
